name: Anonymous
sub: Being genuinely hopeless.
com:
#1: I have been clinically diagnosed with "moderate-high levels" of psychopathy.
#2: This stems from "miraculously" surviving being struck with a hammer when I was an infant.
#3: I have no empathy for others.

I'm hopeless in terms of love. By all accounts I only really care about myself. I understand the concept of empathy, but for me it is a grueling and agonizing process of pretending to care by taking active measures to remember things about people, judging their situations by what how i've seen others judge similar situations, and rolling with it until I get what I want.

Out of the several intimate and personal relationships i've had with women, there has only been one that I didn't end on my own terms, and that one ended because her family "got the creeps" from me (which isn't uncommon for me) and pressured her into dumping me. Every single relationship after that one ended with me telling them that I do not care about them at all, usually out of the blue once I grew bored of them.

The way I understand how love works is one that I don't earnestly believe I will ever experience due to having a physical amount of brain damage that severely inhibits my ability to care about others. Yes, I've had x-rays, CT scans, MRI's, i've bene prescribed several drugs over the past 30 years. I, in terms of love, am screwed.

I'm not asking for advice, but I am trying to throw some out there for those that like to lie to themselves. You and I, we're not the same. You are not hopeless, you're just a crybaby thats afraid of failure. Think of "working on yourself" as if you're going to college. Do it, and dont expect any results for at least 4 years. Thats where most of you fail, and that failure reinforced your own internal monologue of "i'm hopeless". Stop that shit and see a therapist for at least 3 years WHILE legitimately working on yourself, and chances are you'll be fine.

Yes, in some aspects, however my "unattainable" goal is something that, at least for the moment, I can't throw money at to fix. If medical science gets to a point where it can reverse or otherwise undo my brain damage, i'd be happy.
I make a middling 7 figures.
I have a house is far bigger than I need.
I have live-in escorts.
I'm 49 years old, with no children.
To some, i'm living the dream, and I don't see it that way, nothing fills the void of resentment and hatred that exists in my mind, knowing that there is something that I strictly * CANNOT* have. I crave it to the point where I have three therapists and two psychologists that I see every single week to maintain low levels of bitterness, combined with a cocktail of mood stabilizers to keep me presentable.
This is not life, for me, this is existing.

"The grass is always greener on the other side" is a thing that pops up all the time. If I could go trade everything I have to go backwards in time and stop that attack on me, I would do so. Maybe I would still turn out the same, but maybe I wouldn't, and would be able to care about others enough to actually be happy.

I have a problem that no one acknowledges how hard it is to make friends as an adult. This stuff takes effort and for most people including me putting in real effort is not a feel good kind of thing. Even when it comes to finding friends online it's the same thing.

A ton of people are set in their own ways and they are occupied with their responsibilities. Most of the time the busyness is going to be an indefinite thing until old age. Even in college this is normal. Most of us aren't going to be in an environment where friendships foster and grow.

Like duh I have to take my classes, carve out time to study for those classes, and attend to my own responsibilities like work, housekeeping, exercise, running errands, and getting decent sleep.

The only people I know who get to have fun in college are people who have most if not everything paid off or they don't give a shit about their studying and health. They are in a position where they have safety nets and because of those safety nets they are allowed to take risks, but for me I'm vulnerable. I wanted to say that just in case the college schizo comes rolling into the thread.

We shouldn't be stigmatizing loneliness, it's bullshit and it makes the situation worse for everyone. I just wanted to speak about this to get out of my mind.

sub: How do I start a conversation without being awkward?
com:
I have a friend on Discord I really miss. I try joining new servers to meet new people and they all suck.

For the last few months, we've been on great terms. We used to VC every other night and look at stuff on YouTube or whatever and have a great time.

Recently, due to some drama with another group of friends, they've decided to cut contact with them and leave all the servers they share with both them and me, so I can only DM them. Since then, it's been a while since we've really spoken to each other, so me trying to make a move would be really sudden and unnatural, especially considering the small time frame in which we used to hang out.

I wanna bring myself to just be up-front ask how they're doing, if they wanna do something sometime, etc. But I can't help feeling like any attempt I could make to re-establish a connection would seem forced and weird to them, like they'd think I'm desperate. I sometimes send them cute cat pics/vids with a little message attached, trying to get them to engage with me, but I get nothing. And even when I do get a response, say, to a direct question, they'll usually answer in the most vague and terse way possible.

And I can't see inside their head. I don't know if this is because they don't like me or because they don't know what to respond with, so they say as little as possible. And I don't really hold it against them for either reason. I just wish I could get a little insight.

Anyway, sorry about the wall of text.
TL;DR, I haven't spoken to an old friend in ages and things are super awkward, so I want to hit them up again to see how they're doing, but I want to do it right. I want to be friends with them again. How do I approach the subject?

Tell me I'm being retarded if I am. I just want a second opinion on this before I make a decision.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>27887278
I usually ask people "got any plans this weekend"?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>27887278
>I just wish I could get a little insight.
Something you need to learn to recognize is that this is not considerate like you think it is, it's actually you being neurotically focused on controlling others. You cannot control others or how they like you, and you'll never be perfect enough for everyone to enjoy your company.

Anyway you're talking about digital conversation but I'm gonna give advice on talking to people, in person. It can definitely feel awkward or forced at first especially if you are anxious or sensitive to it. This can be reduced by socializing beforehand elsewhere intentionally to get your social skills all primed and ready. Additionally in some cases the way you open a conversation is going to feel forced or awkward and you won't be able to make it not feel that way. In those cases you can either lean into it jokingly (if they pick up on the vibe) or ignore it and continue. Some of the best conversations, social situations, and flirts I've experienced started from really hamfisted openings or situations. Oftentimes these get forgotten or people don't care about them or sometimes as I said before, they're inescapable. Socializing before hand does though seem to help put you into the flow of social skills, back into the fray of it.

Just say what you mean and have confidence in that, if they bite then great if they don't then you lost nothing you didn't already not have.

Does that make me look desperate? Yes. Do I care? No. I want to interact with them as much as I can and I am open about that.
Being genuine has downsides but it will help you find genuine people, and they are who make life worth living IMO

name: Anonymous
com: I know that my life is shit and I am shit but I'm content with this. It's not just comfort from being this way for a long time and knowing nothing else, either, it's that I've deluded myself into thinking it's better not to try and that it's better to be an outcast and have 'normies' look at you like a freak. What do I do?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
The first thing is to recognize that these sorts of thoughts are delusions that spring from low self esteem. For example most normies are likely not looking at you like a freak. Most people don't care about other people at all.

Once you become able to recognize that your self esteem is in fact low you can catch these thoughts as they happen and reduce their impact on your emotional subconscious, at least to some extent.

Next, you will want to work on improving your self esteem. This will not be simply easy unfortunately. Try to understand that seeing onself in a positive light is a personal battle more than anything else. Are you failing to meet your own expectations? If not, what is stopping you? Or perhaps recognize that your standards for yourself are illogical and unobtainable.

Often times ones self image is a product of how they perceive other people see them. You can improve your appearance with better self care, buying better clothes, and working out and improve how people see your personality by making sure to always be friendly and polite. This will not magnetically get people to like you but recognize there is no trick to doing that. The fact is people can be hard to read or just be spergs themselves. Try to recognize that their ultimate opinion of you should not affect how you perceive yourself.

Or you could continue living in cynical apathy but this will never just right itself without some motivation on your part, your choice.

>Am I being an asshole for feeling this way?
Don't label feelings in this way "am I (whatever) for feeling this". That's entirely bullshit. Feel your feelings. The goal is to understand why you feel them and whether the beliefs/ideas/thoughts behind those feelings are serving you and the life you have/want. What you're feeling is common and normal, especially in older "historical" friendships, the ones that continue on long after their expiry due to shared history. The issue here is your communication in this relationship, and also the toxic nature of being EMPLOYED BY YOUR FRIEND (major no no, but whatever, moving on from that point since that's not what your post is about). You saw your friend react in a way that told you something was up. You can't know that for sure till you ask her. You didn't. Then the same thing happened on your end. You're growing resentful for not communicating your desire to hang out with her/go on the trip, and feeling hurt due to not being seen by this friend. She could feel the same way. You have to talk to her about this stuff, about these real issues. It's awkward and uncomfortable at first but the more accustomed you get to forgoing social bullshit and getting to real conversations and real communication, the easier it becomes to navigate these lanes and start fostering intimacy and authenticity in your relationships.

Like....9 times out of 10 when I go out on a limb or get vulnerable with the people I care about, it's like opening the door to a blooming greenhouse filled with flowers. So much is on the other side of it that's so beautiful, often pleasant but even if it's not it's always great and beyond expectation in a good way.

sub: Why can't I hold down a friendship, why can't I have friends? What is wrong with me?
com:
If you meet me, I am an incredible social person, I can have conversations, I am radiation confidence, I am, in short just a charismatic SOB. The problem starts when I am living somewhere new. I am basically incapable of forming a deeper connection with people or having, yeah, friends and I am incredibly lonely because of this.

I am in my semester abroad where I came a little late, like after the introduction week, but still got on with the people pretty well. A month in, I basically broke off contact with everybody here. I had the same, when I started my 1st year of uni. I have some people I smoke with sometimes and that is it, apart from that I am just in my room 24/7 or in Uni. I cant sleep, I cant do work, I am playing games to avoid my loneliness. I am desperate to go home in a week and fyi, I hate it so much.

The thing is, in the beginning I was like, I don’t want to have friends, but I need friends and then I fell into this vicious cycle where I cant escape anymore. I know, I just need to write some people, pursue my hobbies and so on, but I am absolutely paralysed by fear and anxiety when I have to think about reapproaching people. Furthermore, I do not have any idea what to write them. So I am basically fucked. And I hate myself even more for this. And then I am way to anxious to develop a strategy.

I am so desperate to not be lonely anymore, but I am so deep in my depression with that, that I am on the border of becoming crazy.

Then, the friends I have, I feel only hanging out with because they are the last option I have. And this is a shitty feeling as well.

I don’t want to live like this. I want to go out, I want to have fun, I want to experience live and I do not want to be so fucking lonely anymore.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>27885311
A lot of what you are saying seems like a phase but the essential problem of depression and loneliness will unfortunately be a reoccuring theme even when things do change unless you nip that in the bud.

From my point of view friends are only as strong as the trust that is shared. Having said that I think the surest and easisest way to earn trust is to be invited into a person's living space or to be able to invite them to your own.

Adult relationships seem to be about making each other feel comfortable (go, figure). So between now and leaving Uni, it would be a good idea to learn what activities are worth giving out invitations for. At the same time learn what is worth making a suggestion to invite yourself over for whilst respecting boundaries. I guess the old saying "mi casa es su casa" is very relevant huh?

Essentially my advice is that you want to practice giving comfort to others so that you can accommodate their whims. Finally, to accelerate the process I suggest when meeting your new friends again, you should deliberately bring a newer new friend and introduce them to each other then rinse and repeat with each successful connection.

Hobbies, interest and all this other "personality" stuff does not matter to anynbody in hindsight. If you can provide comfort to a lot of people, having friends will be effortless indeed.

Oh and btw
>If you meet me, I am an incredible social person, I can have conversations, I am radiation confidence, I am, in short just a charismatic SOB.
If you're not doing so already, you should volunteer with a decent charity for at least 1 day a week.
